image.altText: Armoured Israeli heavy earthmoving equipment abandoned on a sealed road near a massive concrete border wall.

props.synopsis: The ABC takes you to the border between the two countries, hours after a ceasefire between Israel and Hezbollah came into force.

title.children: Barbed wire, mud, concrete walls and burnt-out cars — the scars of war along the 'blue line'

image.altText: A green backdrop with a black and white cutout of Anthony Albanese. He's surrounded by social media icons

props.synopsis: While the teen social media ban has passed parliament, questions are being asked about how the age of all users will be verified — and even the viability of the new law.

title.children: Lurking underneath the teen social media ban is an unsettling game of Would You Rather

image.altText: A photo of a small, messy bedroom with two beds, a clothes horse and other furniture strewn around

props.synopsis: Sydney's housing crisis is evolving into a hidden health crisis and as rents soar, some residents face an impossible choice: unaffordable housing or unsafe living conditions.

title.children: The dark side of Sydney's housing crisis: 20 people in two-bed apartments and shocking health risks

image.altText: A composite picture of a woman in black-and-white and a man in colour, both looking serious.

props.synopsis: The decisions the Reserve Bank makes affect the rest of us, and therefore should continue not to be taken lightly — whichever board might make them.

title.children: The struggle over Australia's economic outlook is being fought in the shadows

image.altText: A scuba diver with a yellow tape measure over an array of bleached acropora species with a school of jellyfish above them.

props.synopsis: New modelling reveals some outer reefs will stay 1 degree Celsius cooler than surrounding areas in coming decades -- but it's not clear how their coral colonies will fare.

title.children: Two cool spots found in the Great Barrier Reef where corals may survive warming oceans

image.altText: Ryan Kobayashi and two women hold pictures of missing woman Hannah Kobayashi.

props.synopsis: Hannah Kobayashi vanished somewhere in LA while on her way from Hawaii to New York City, and her father died days after arriving to search for her, leading to wild theories from online sleuths as authorities continue their investigations.

title.children: On a layover in LA, Hannah vanished without a trace. Then came strange texts and worrying CCTV

image.altText: A man wearing a turban.

props.synopsis: Hezbollah chief Naim Qassem has declared his organisation has scored a "divine victory" in its year-long war with Israel that paused as part of a ceasefire deal last week.

title.children: Hezbollah chief says group has scored 'divine victory' against Israel

image.altText: A phone screen showing social media apps.

props.synopsis: From the end of next year, children under 16 will be banned from social media in Australia. So how do parents feel about enforcing the nation's controversial new laws?

title.children: For some parents, the 'blanket rule' of Australia's under-16 social media ban can't come soon enough

image.altText: a group exercises on bikes at a weight loss camp

props.synopsis: Beijing has launched a three-year plan to tackle obesity, with rates of overweight children and adults rapidly increasing in just a few years.

title.children: 'They love kids to be chubby': China grapples with 'looming obesity crisis'

image.altText: Ross Coulthart in his home study holding his book: In Plain Sight.

props.synopsis: An institute, founded by an Australian-based entrepreneur, wants to better understand unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAP) and is funding research projects in the hope of answering the question, "Are we alone?"

title.children: Are we alone? Australian institute funds research into unexplained phenomena

image.altText: Mr Pavel and Mr Albanese shaking hands in a room

props.synopsis: Decorated former NATO military commander Petr Pavel says democratic nations need to cooperate more in the face of threats to Taiwan, Ukraine, and global free trade.

title.children: Visiting Czech President Petr Pavel urges democratic leaders to engage more with Taiwan

image.altText: A woman standing out the front of UK parliament

props.synopsis: The House of Commons' vote paves the way for assisted dying to be offered to those with terminal illnesses.

title.children: 'We need this': UK parliament backs voluntary assisted dying bill

image.altText: A woman surrounded by other pro-independence demonstrators holds up a Kanak flag behind her back.

props.synopsis: The European power spends billions of euros on New Caledonia and faces a large damage bill from this year's violent unrest. Why is it hanging on?

title.children: Why one of Australia's closest neighbours remains valuable to this European power

image.altText: Tow children walking amid tents in Gaza, one is holding a bucket and has his hand placed on younger sibling's back.

props.synopsis: Children in war-torn areas like Sudan and Gaza are suffering more than before, a new report suggests, as grave violations against them jump to the highest level we've seen in over two decades.

title.children: Children inside Gaza wish for an 'end to the war'. But their lives are more in danger now than for decades

image.altText: A man holding a microphone in one hand eats a banana with duck-tape hanging from it in the other

props.synopsis: Justin Sun fulfilled his promise to eat the controversial artwork at a glamorous hotel in Hong Kong, describing the taste as "really quite good".

title.children: The crypto mogul who bought banana artwork Comedian for $9.5 million just ate it

image.altText: A man in a blue jacket and black cap leans on a white post outside a building smiling

props.synopsis: Dong Yuyu has been published in several international publications and is well-respected around the world.

title.children: A Chinese journalist has been jailed for spying, prompting an outcry from his family and rights groups

image.altText: Two people play pool in an outback pub.

props.synopsis: When tree-changers Frank and Debbie Wust bought the pub that starred in Crocodile Dundee just over a decade ago, they had no idea it also meant helping to run an outback community.

title.children: In the outback, running a pub means more than pouring beers

image.altText: An Indigenous man with long grey hair leaves court.

props.synopsis: The 72-year-old south-west Victorian Indigenous leader has been jailed for six years and two months over 25 fraud-related charges.

title.children: Former ATSIC head Geoff Clark jailed for defrauding Framlingham Indigenous community

image.altText: Peter Garrett sings into a microphone on stage, dressed in a blue shirt under colourful orange and red lights.

props.synopsis: The orchestra says the former Midnight Oil frontman and ex-arts minister has cancelled his leadership of its review because of other commitments.

title.children: Peter Garrett no longer leading investigation into the MSO's policies

image.altText: Scaffolding around the Notre Dame cathedral, backgrounded by blue sky

props.synopsis: The bells of Notre Dame are chiming again, but scaffolding still clinging to the cathedral's exterior is puzzling some Parisians.

title.children: Notre Dame is finally reopening after a devastating 2019 fire. But why does it still look unfinished?

image.altText: Eight books covers sit on a pale background, including Niall Williams Time of the Child and Inga Simpson's The Thinning.

props.synopsis: If you're looking to stack up your summer reading pile, here's an excellent starting point, with new releases from Rosalie Ham, Lech Blaine, Haruki Murakami and more.

title.children: Planning a summer of great reading? Here are our recommendations

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shir, black hat and sunglasses holding a carton of eggs in a field.

props.synopsis: Blasting AC/DC and sorting through hundreds of eggs is how Jinda Holland spends most of his working days. At 39, it is one of only a handful of jobs he has ever had and it is his favourite by far.

title.children: The chicken farm giving people living with disability a crack at the job market, one egg at a time

image.altText: A woman in a pink shirt and glasses holds a newspaper.

props.synopsis: The Broken Hill Times rolled out its first edition during major power outages in the region as the Country Press Association says the regional print industry is getting stronger.

title.children: New Broken Hill Times newspaper disrupts narrative regional media on the way out

image.altText: A group of men in camouflage gear holding rifles disembark from the back of a truck in a desert environment.

props.synopsis: Syrian insurgents have breached Syria's second-largest city, Aleppo, and are clashing with government forces on the city's western edge, according to a Syrian war monitor as well as fighters themselves.

title.children: Syrian rebels breach city of Aleppo in shock offensive, catching Assad government forces by surprise

image.altText: Composite Andrew David and Maurice Hawell outside court

props.synopsis: Three men from Sydney have been sentenced to prison over their sexual assaults against three women in their late teens, with the longest term being 14 years.

title.children: Bucks party trio handed lengthy jail sentences for 'cold, callous, degrading' gang rape of three women

image.altText: A blurry image of a boat sinking

props.synopsis: Mistakes by members of the crew caused a New Zealand navy ship to plough into a reef off the coast of Samoa, where it caught fire and sank, according to the preliminary findings of a military Court of Inquiry.

title.children: Inquiry reveals crew errors sank New Zealand navy ship off Samoa

image.altText: A Ukrainian officer next to a downed Shahed drone pointing to a thermobaric charge beside it.

props.synopsis: Russia is carrying out record mass drone attacks on Ukraine, and experts say its new foam decoys and thermobaric warheads were making them more devastating and difficult to defend against.

title.children: Russia is using foam drones and 'vacuum' bomb Shaheds to carry out devastating mass attacks on Ukraine

image.altText: Fatima Payman

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's vote was needed to pass a critical reform. It was late on Wednesday the prime minister's office realised it was about to collapse.

title.children: Payman adds to intrigue over crashed environmental overhaul

image.altText: Composite image of Simona Halep and Iga Świątek.

props.synopsis: Former world number one Simona Halep expresses dismay at the way Iga Świątek's doping case was addressed by tennis authorities compared to her own.

title.children: 'A big difference': Halep questions handling of Swiatek's doping case

image.altText: Sun shines against power pole in NSW.

props.synopsis: The latest independent scorecard shows that Australia is falling behind in its bid to meet the government's legislated 2030 target.

title.children: Australia falls dramatically short of 2030 emissions reduction goal, latest independent scorecard shows

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

props.synopsis: There are new laws for supermarkets, housing developers, victims of sexual violence, the Reserve Bank and many more, after the government ticked off dozens of items on its to-do list in a single night.

title.children: Australia's laws have suddenly changed on tax benefits and 12 other big issues

image.altText: Two reconstructions of ancient human species side by side, one very ape looking the other a broad faced human-like head.

props.synopsis: Newly discovered fossil footprints indicate two different ancient human relatives walked upright around a muddy lake in Kenya.

title.children: Footprints suggest two types of ancient human relatives walked side by side 1.5 million years ago

image.altText: A side on shot of a man wearing a black suit next to a woman in a black blazer walking looking ahead.

props.synopsis: Kristian White remains on bail, avoiding time behind bars ahead of sentencing for the manslaughter of 95-year-old Clare Nowland in an aged-care home.

title.children: Family of 95yo who died after being tasered by cop 'struggling to understand' why he remains on bail after guilty verdict

image.altText: A composite image of AFLW players Jasmine Garner, Breanna Koenen, Kim  Rennie and Dakota Davidson.

props.synopsis: There are a lot of emotions that go into the lead up of a grand final. Here's how each side and their coaches are tackling them.

title.children: 'Coin of football': How each side tackles the different emotions that come with grand final day
